list.item: Details of interruptions that break into our schedule

div1.p:
Dearest Jane - Sunday afternoon and a beautiful day though cold enough in the house to make a furnace fire desirable - Our little frosty spell is over and yesterday p.m. it tried to get warm and rainy again. Wonder what you are all doing today. Picture you enjoying a ride somewhere. Do you suppose I'll remember how to drive? At last the baskets are ready to send - so you may expect them about the time this letter arrives. The big one is not strong enough to go through the mail like the others so put it in the box with a small one as the sack was not large enough for the three small ones together as I first expected to send them. Among the newspapers in the box you will find a few sweet peppers they look like ours only are not peppery. We cut some & ate with
rice and gravy for dinner today. I have seen them as yellow as can be but could not get them to send you - nor have I been able to get the October beans & the persimmons they say are too soft to send. Have you even eaten them? Funny little things! The big basket is yours & the other Nellie's while in the sack is one for Jo & Mabel. Hope they suit. I like them very much especially yours Jane - Am sending the small kind to Aunt Lottie - Aunt Carrie & Charlotte & want a couple more for Maudie & Fannie. These are about all I can do for Christmas presents except the immediate family.

I wonder if you would just as soon call up Miss Lathrop or
have Nellie K. do it & find out where she got the paint for our wooden toys two years ago. It was a powder which we mixed with water & glue & which we have not been able to get in Knoxville. Ask her what Chicago firm or some other place near us would have it? Whether a school supply house or regular paint store.

Since writing you Wed eve. have not done anything of note. Darned - looked over my papers & prepared lessons - visited with Miss Langmaid & fussed around generally. Dr. Massey blew in Friday & brought along a grand beef roast. Evelyn always cuts off a few slices to fry for supper when he brings one - The Red Cross meeting was at 6:30 so we went over with our lamps as usual - Some of the young people came & only a few - very few of the older - I had taken down the big map and put up the Red Cross posters that Charlotte sent - they came just at the right time and look very pretty. My photogravers look very nice too - on the piano have one of the baskets filled with hemlock branches while on a flower stand below my little silk flag is another with pine branches & cones. Across the panels at the back are pages of thin writing and printing. We had expected a speaker from Sevierville but they phoned up that the roads were too bad & though told it was possible for a car to get through now - no one arrived. Evelyn & Miss Langmaid talked some - also an ex-soldier Charlie Clabo - then we sang & sang & that finished it.

Yesterday was a busy day - We (Emily & I) did our sweeping right after breakfast - I packed up the baskets too - fixed my room - got some films ready to send off - another mean little job - made the war cake & cleaned up myself. Aunt Lizzie didn't feel good & went to bed before supper - Mrs. Proffitt was over as Mr. C. & Abbie both went home this weekend. Mrs. Huff & Stella came over with some friends of their from Knoxville a Mrs. Borlin & her daughter. Emily & I are going to try to go over to Huff's some night this week & stay. She has been wanting us to do it for a long time & we had
planned to go last night if these friends hadn't arrived. So many interruptions all day long here - a Mrs McCarter came before breakfast to have Evelyn call up Knoxville General Hospital to find out about her son Arlie (had him in school a little while) whose hand had been hurt. Far a wonder she was able to get a message through & then had to write a letter for her - (she can't read nor write). Then a Mr. Jerry Whaley came to have a message sent - Richard Ogle came to have make some hearth brooms - Otha Reagan & his father were hauling up our wood - Isorie
came to get rags soap etc. to scrub up the school - etc. etc. There is a great coming & going here. The only place not to be interrupted is off in the woods or shut up in your room
as I am now.

This morning was Sunday School as usual after which Emily & I walked a mile or more up Baskin's with the Ogle girls & after much difficulty managed to get away without having to stay to dinner. Wore my new bouquet - which everyone admired muchly - It is surely awfully cute! We saw so many butterflies on our walk - think of that!
This is rather a stupid letter I fear but am really rather sleepy for some reason or other & not a bit newsy -

Miss Langmaid is very very nice - extremely calm & placid in her way but inexorable too - one would never dream of running in opposition to her wishes unless absolutely necessary! She used to have one of Aunt Lizzie's nieces in school - Exy for short - from Ex' a mine! Think of that for a name. The machinery for chair factory & dishes are at Sevierville but not here yet - the site for the factory isn't settled as yet so the machinery doesn't matter but we do long for our dishes! Evelyn tries to find someone to who is coming this way to bring up our stuff rather than make a special trip after it.
Will write again in a day or so - with loads of love to you all as ever -
